Package chessapi4j

Class Position

  • java.lang.Object
    • chessapi4j.Position
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable
    public final class Position
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Position representation.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    lunalobos
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Constructs a Position from a FEN string.

      If this method returns true means this position is checkmate.

      If this method returns true means this position can be draw according to Fifty Moves's rule.

      Checks if the game is over.
      boolean isLackOfMaterial()
      If this method returns true means this position is a draw because of lack of material.
      boolean isLongCastleBlack()
      If this method returns true means black is able to castle queen side.
      boolean isLongCastleWhite()
      If this method returns true means white is able to castle queen side.
      boolean isRepetitions()
      If this method returns true means this position is a draw because of repetitions.
      boolean isShortCastleBlack()
      If this method returns true means black is able to castle king side.
      boolean isShortCastleWhite()
      If this method returns true means white is able to castle king side.
      boolean isStalemate()
      If this method returns true means this position is a draw because of stalemate.
      boolean isWhiteMove()
      If this method returns true means it is white turn to move, otherwise it is black turn.

        piece - the piece ordinal to set

        Overrides:

      • getSquares

        public int[] getSquares()
        This method returns a 64 length array. It contains the piece value for each square according to Piece ordinal values.

        Each index represents a square, the value represents a piece

        ---------Board---------

        56 57 58 59 60 61 62 63

        48 49 50 51 52 53 54 55

        40 41 42 43 44 45 46 47

        32 33 34 35 36 37 38 39

        24 25 26 27 28 29 30 31

        16 17 18 19 20 21 22 23

        08 09 10 11 12 13 14 15

        00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07

        Returns:
        the squares array

      • setSquares

        public void setSquares​(int[] squares)
        Sets the squares array. This will be reflected in the the bits array. Each element of this array is a square and its value is a piece ordinal. The square number corresponds to the element index.
        Parameters:
        squares - the squares

      • isGameOver

        public boolean isGameOver()
        Checks if the game is over.

        The game is over if it is checkmate, stalemate, fifty moves, lack of material or repetitions.

        Returns:
        true if the game is over, false otherwise
        Since:
        1.2.6

      • isDraw

        public boolean isDraw()
        Retrieves if the current position is a forced draw.

        A position is considered a draw if it results from stalemate, the fifty-move rule, insufficient material, or threefold repetition.

        Returns:
        true if the position is a draw, false otherwise
        Since:
        1.2.6

      • setBits

        public void setBits​(long[] bits)
        Sets the array of bitboards, length has to be always 12. Setting a different length array will lead to unpredictable behavior.
        Parameters:
        bits - the bitboard array

      • getBits

        public long[] getBits()
        Returns the bitboards array in ordinal order excluding EMPTY. This means that index 0 represents white pawns, index 1 represents white knights and so on.
        Returns:
        the array of bitboards

      • setEnPassant

        public void setEnPassant​(int enPassant)
        Sets en passant value.

        Setting this value manually could potentially lead to inconsistencies.

        Parameters:
        enPassant - the en passant square

      • getEnPassant

        public int getEnPassant()
        Returns the index square of the piece that can be capture using en passant rule, even when is not possible for any pawn to reach.

        This is no the square that is shown in fen representation, is the pawn that can be capture location. Fen representation shows the place where an hypothetical pawn will end after using the en passant rule to capture a pawn in the represented position.

        For a position like "rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/4P3/8/PPPP1PPP/RNBQKBNR b KQkq e3 0 1" this method will return the square index for e4, 28.

        Returns:
        the index square of the piece that can be capture using en passant rule

      • setMovesCounter

        public void setMovesCounter​(int movesCounter)
        Sets moves counter value.
        Parameters:
        movesCounter - the moves counter

      • getMovesCounter

        public int getMovesCounter()
